comments.commentBody: Except Niles is such a sweetie!

"we could end up splitting the country in two, empowering Islamic radicals and creating a bigger humanitarian disaster than the one we hoped to forestall. The worst-case situation has not come to pass in Libya itself."

Yes, it has. We seem to have split the country in three, if not shattered it into tribes. We have empowered everything in it, including Islamic radicals, and created a massive arms flow to other Islamic radicals. The place teeters on the edge of chaos, which could easily be that bigger humanitarian disaster any day.

But yes, Mali is twice as big and has suffered even worse.

Those who want to feed the rebels with arms and money and advisers and equipment in Syria consider all of this a success. They constantly say so. It is a powerful indictment of their new idea to do it all again in a country four times bigger and more central to everything else sensitive.

The global warming faith has more than 100 million worshippers in the U.S. Your demands for government policy intervention on behalf of a religious movement violates the separation of church and state.

With so many believers, the global warming clerics should have no problem insisting that their flock immediately make personal behavior modification to zero their own personal carbon footprint. The technologies are all sitting there waiting to be purchased, installed and used. Because it will be, someday, catastrophic, ending all life on Earth, there is no limit on how much the faithful should be willing to pay...out of their own pockets. Remember, its for the children.

Unless this happens, the global warming faith will continue to have zero credibility.

Nice story on a very interesting project. The collection of stories obtained throughout his journey is far more valuable than the cards in the set. Good luck to Mr. Mortimer acquiring the next one.

Matt Raymond
Autograph University
http://www.AutographU.com
This is what collecting is all about. Just usually NOT this extreme.
you do know the White Sox are leading their division, right?
Watching Dunn be the 21st century Kingman is not a reason to buy White Sox tickets (or even put them on TV).
Allow me to coin a second rate Yogi-ism:  Just when ya think ya got this game figured out, ya don't!"

Anybody still awake out there? Took me nearly an hour after I got home tonight but finally wrestled this tough puzzle into submission.

IGY was my first entry--not only a big fan of Mr. Fagen/Steely Dan, but the IGY included 1957 (as in Jimbo57). I knew KNOWONESONIONS but it took a while for it to float to the surface.

Had DIED instead of WENT for 5D and KOOKY instead of WACKY for 30A but finally concluded they weren't helping. KOOKY would've been better clued in reference to the Addams Family, anyway.

I always dig the ANTEGGs out of my yum khai mod daeng and leave them on the SIDE of the DISH.

Hall of Fame pitcher Dennis Eckersley went by the nickname ECK.
The knob supplement on Ruben's bat was a great idea. I'm waiting for a foul pole HR.
Why isn't R.A. Dickey and his buckling knuckler on the "Prospering Pitchers" list?

Well duh its hard enough for us young adults to find a job.  With so many older/more qualified people willing to do low paying jobs that used to have to be filled by inexperienced teenagers it's pretty obvious that there are less summer jobs for teenagers.  As for the income disparity that's pretty easily explained by the fact that families with money have hook ups and can usually get some family friend or business associate to hire their privileged teenager.

I like this! The carpeted floor is important because it more or less preserves the orientation the can landed with. A sandbox might be better.

The liquid content could be a factor because the chili in the cans may not completely follow the roll of the can, but since rolling takes place after landing I woudn't worry about that.

BTW do you give the cans any rotation when you toss? I'd be careful to avoid rotation about the cylinder axis because then you turn the can into a gyroscope. You can easily check if the spin you give it makes a difference.

Alex,
Great photographs and fascinating conversation with you, family, and neighbors tonight. Best of luck.

You can catch the edge landing modes if  you allow the coins to fall into a basin filled with sand or sawdust.  Or maybe a viscous liquid like heavy oil or honey?  That will allow the edge-down orientation to last longer, I think.

Hey -- the "number play fix" algorithm now automatically resizes the graphics -- neat!!

Thank you, GH!

A colleague was in a bus that hit a cow while coming down the mountain a couple of months ago. I've been in multiple cars and marshrootkas that have had to stop because the lead cow decided it was time for the herd to cross the road. I even saw a herd wandering the super highway about 30 km from Gori.

Even without any of the other factors like marshrootka drivers passing while looking into the whites of the oncoming drivers eyes or internationals with drivers who can't wait, the bovine menace is going to kill someone. I hope it isn't me.

Any comparison to the Third Reich - may its memory be blotted out - shows that the author is not interested in a serious discussion of these complex issues. There is absolutely no comparing the two. There are more than a dozen Jewish Israeli groups who advocate and pursue court cases on behalf of Palestinians. There are usually 10-12 Arab Israelis serving in Parliament. There is an active effort to address the failure to integrate non-Jewish Israelis into society as Israel grapples with how to integrate the ultra-Haredi population as well.  The Third Reich had as its stated goal the complete domination of Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals. Unlike Israel, Germany was in no way threatened or surrounded by countries publicly proclaiming their intent to destroy it.

What an amazing over reaction to a fairly nuanced article. Ordinary people don't read an article that lays out both sides of the issue, says Bangladesh has some justifications for it's position, but urges them to try harder, and then claim "most hypocritical ever".

What is it with commentors who must twist America into every article printed on here. Are you not capable of reading something in it's own context. The article is about Rohingya refuge's and Bangladesh. Let them have their media exposure, they need it it without the context being dragged away from them.

Saudi Arabia, which has competed in the summer Olympics since 1972, should never have been allowed by the IOC to enter into Olympic and international competition because of their discriminatory policies against women (just as South Africa was banned for its apartheid policies). However, now that they have "bowed" to international pressure and will allow women to compete, Saudi leaders are in a bind. Since girls can't play sports at school, how long will they be required to practice their sport in secret?  Of course, they could train outside the country - oh wait, they need a male family member to agree to their travel plans.  Then, what happens if a girl decides to become a gymnast?  Will Saudi leaders decide what sports are appropriate because of clothing requirements? It is sad to think that 50% of Saudi's population is held with such disregard and so little respect.
It has been proven to last at least 2000 years without a dent.

"At a dinner party in a private home, men and women mixed freely and ladies left their abayas at the door."

I've always wondered how much longer this institutionalized hypocrisy can survive, and why it's lasted as long as it has.

One way to assure that liberation id impeded is to rub a regime's nose in it, insuring an in country backlash and response.

Yes, this is a remarkable event. Yes, I would like to see more. But events move more quickly on a calm rather than a rough sea.

The military junta killed 3000+ of its own citizens and later changed the country's name from Burma to Myanmar. From history point of view, such killings took place in "Burma" and not in "Myanmar".

Than Shwe and his cronies can change names, make the constitution for their own safety and ignore the people's voice, but they cannot change history.

I agree with the author - please don't call us "Myanmarese".
I visited about 8 years ago and experienced much of the confusion and difficulties of what is discussed here.  Thanks for the myanmarese.

Though Bibi Netanyahu was a natural and didn't need much schooling,when it came down to manipulating large populations of religious extremists for political gain he still learned a great deal from his American  mentors, Dick Cheney, Mitch McConnell, Karl Rove, John Boehner, Tom DeLay, G.W. Bush and many more.

Journalist Swe Win's tongue-in-cheek ponderings about the infernal problem of Burma versus Myanmar is the best I have read as yet.....the best shtick ever! All that fuss and we get to be called Myanmarese by some unlearned Westerners is like having a thorn got into our sides.

A Myanmar/Burmese sitting on the fence.
